comments.commentBody: The flub matters.  She's supposed to be a professional who learned and rehearsed the words and the notes. "O'er the ramparts we watched, were so gallantly streaming" may be one of the least understood lines, but if we are Americans it is our responsibility to learn not only the lyrics but what they mean, and the history of why and when they were written.  Is that too much to ask of a national performer?

Who needs smart guys like you when Sarah Palin told us all this way back in early November of last year?

Back then, Palin said, "Everyone who ever goes out shopping for groceries knows that prices have risen significantly over the past year or so." Well, "everyone," including me, made fun of Palin because she was pretty much wrong. PolitiFact, which goes out on a limb to give politicians the benefit of the doubt, rated her claim "barely true."

Ah, but. As we all know, Palin can see Russia from her house. Evidently she took advantage of the special insights inherent in her convenient proximity to the source of the problem. You have to give her a lot of credit for reviewing global weather data, analyzing world commodity consumption patterns, calculating demand fluctuations (who knew Palin was a Keynesian?), factoring in the food price elasticities and the effects of Chinese currency manipulation, generating a macro model – then phrasing her results in language the everyday grocery shopper can understand. What a prescient genius!

Nice try, though, Krugman.

Here's food for thought that's a counterpoint to the “global food crisis” Paul discusses in his post. But hopefully it offers insights into the interplay of rising food prices, weather disruptions and why the usual suspects go wild. We overlook in our search for truth that stories have an older half-life, greater social power, and have historically eclipsed the truth. Truth once was directly observed; market goods were stacked.
Stories embellished and altered for our entertainment what we all knew was the truth underneath.

In a society of 300 million, that underlying truth is hard to find. So we substitute our personal untethered versions. But our need for mindless entertainment has exploded. Last week I read many posts of the Krugman ancillary entertainment industry, the legions of columnists, blogs, comments, and web sites whose raison d'etre is to strike at Paul Krugman not through examining his conclusions or invalidating his reasoning, but by saying “he's wrong because we all know he is wrong (wink or stare or angry scrawl) and this example and interpretation proves unequivocally in its fallacy he is unhappy, washed up, over the hill, failed, Keynesian” and in Paul's words, “evil.”

Of course, I disagree. But it was eye opening to read the sheer volume of vitriol and fantasy that a single person could generate. Especially one who currently holds no public position in government, works in a classroom and writes for the paper we are reading. The stories outsize his influence on government and policy. So while Paul speaks truth (mostly! we disagree on China's errancy and his framing of cultural issues as moral), he has greater value as a invention, as a story, as a means of entertaining the fears and jeers of many, as a target for the public illogic that deflates our fair pride and devalues the important nuances of civil duty. His hard truths make him an easy target. So Paul is a straw man inflated for those whose political appetites include a hearty enjoyment for bread and circuses.

Paul's metrics show our dominant passion is fear. Paul's bokors with their deadening brew sanitize his examples, and smash the supporting detail, model building, and weighing of pros and cons, timeline comparisons and crafted logic that are the character of his posts. The wrong impuned is not a simple omission; it is framed as dangerous and leading to a perilous slide. This cultural formula undergrids the policy battles. But how can there be honest debate, if no view is thought sincere? And all differences are met with scorn?

No matter the economic state, rising or falling, until we recognize and learn from our history, we are condemned to restore the old insanity. If we continue to allow the pursuit of power through money and deceit, our comfort will come from the wrong means and will bring about bad ends. Right now, we would do well to remember the unexpected dangers and delusions that lay in freedom.
--Walter Rhett

To the person who said that paper is fairly clean because it can be recycled and the Internet uses tons of energy I say this:

Calculate the fossil fuel that is burned lugging vast tons of trees to paper mills (you can see them all over the highways in the Pacific Northwest spewing out thick, horrid, black smoke), the oil burned to turn the trees into pulp, transport the pulp to paper mills, transport the heavy paper all over the country, deliver it to homes and stores, pick up all that recycling, transport the recycling to China for processing, process all that recycling, transport the recycled products back to the U.S. and all over the U.S.

There are trucks, trains and ships burning outrageous amounts of fossil fuels all the time, all over the world, due to paper products. I think it is obvious that, although the Internet uses lots of energy, that transporting all these paper-related products is vastly worse.

There is essentially no credible scientific dispute that climate change is occurring and is primarily caused by human activities. For example, as the National Academy of Sciences stated in May 2010:

"The compelling case that climate change is occurring and is caused in large part by human activities is based on a strong, credible body of evidence, says Advancing the Science of Climate Change, one of the new reports. While noting that there is always more to learn and that the scientific process is never “closed,” the report emphasizes that multiple lines of evidence support scientific understanding of climate change. The core phenomenon, scientific questions, and hypotheses have been examined thoroughly and have stood firm in the face of serious debate and careful evaluation of alternative explanations."

Similar conclusions about climate change and its human causes have been reached by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the American Meteorological Society, the American Academy for the Advancement of Science, and the American Geophysical Union.

Unfortunately, our nation's political leaders seem to be unwilling or unable to take serious action to address this threat. The House passed fairly strong cap-and-trade legislation in 2009, but the Obama Administration did not really fight for it and it failed to get the 60 votes needed to overcome Republican obstructionism in the Senate.

Fortunately, there is a plan B – U.S. EPA using its authority under the federal Clean Air Act to regulate CO2 and other greenhouse gas emissions as a pollutant that endangers public health and welfare. The Bush Administration refused to regulate CO2 (despite his campaign promise in 2000 to do so), and had his U.S. EPA decide that CO2 was not a “pollutant” under the Act. The Supreme Court reversed that finding in 2007, leaving it to the Obama Administration’s U.S. EPA to decide whether CO2 emissions endanger public health and welfare. In April 2009, U.S. EPA made such an “endangerment finding,” which paved the way for regulation of CO2 emissions under the Clean Air Act.

The first two sets of U.S. EPA CO2 regulations went into effect earlier this year. They are:

* Automobile standards – Requires fleet-wide reductions in CO2 emissions from cars and light trucks. These reductions translate into increased fuel efficiency standards rising from 30.1 miles per gallon (“mpg”) for cars and trucks for model year 2012 to 35.5mpg for model year 2016.

* New Power Plants and Other Industrial Sources - Requires proposed new power plants or industrial sources to use best available control technology to reduce CO2 emissions. Examples of how to reduce CO2 emissions include increasing plant efficiency, use of lower-CO2 fuels like natural gas or biomass, carbon capture and sequestration, and implementing combined heat and power projects that use the heat created by industrial process to generate electricity, or the excess hot steam created in power plants for certain industrial purposes.

In addition, U.S. EPA is pushing ahead with its plans to develop specific CO2 emission performance standards for power plants and industrial sources over the next couple of years.

While these EPA regulations are far from enough to fully address climate change, they are an important start that will provide a foundation upon which to achieve further reductions in CO2 emissions. In addition, by starting to regulate CO2 emissions, we create more momentum in favor of transitioning to the use of cleaner, lower-CO2 energy sources.

Unfortunately, EPA’s regulatory authority is already under attack from Republicans and some Democrats in coal-dependent states, with the incoming Republican chair of the House Energy and Commerce Committee and Senator Jay Rockefeller (D-WV) calling for at least a two-year delay in any EPA CO2 regulations. So, now is the time to call the White House and urge the Obama Administration to ocmmit to veto any legislation that would curb EPA's authority to regulate CO2, and to call your Congressmembers and urge them to allow EPA to do its job.

He then traced it back to some publicist firm working on behalf of some corporations.

The links is here: http://www.guardian.co.uk...

And as you pointed out after the shootings in Tucson, these people can't win the debate on the merits. They will either post unsubstantiated claims which are not based on probable theory or fact, or they will try to shout down the debate or debase their opponent in the debate, which is you and/or the medium that is publishing your work.

This is a disservice to the public's interest of course. But it also affects real lives. There's a shortage of food, riots develop, people die as a result. So here you are commenting on global warming, something near and dear to the heart of some very wealthy and powerful corporations, so I would expect an onslaught of counter commentary, all of it paid for by corporations wanting to look AstroTurfish.

When nearly half of all Egyptians subsist on $2 a day and nearly $1 of that goes toward food, it's understandable that they want some change to believe in. Their dictator Mubarak, who reportedly has billions stashed in Swiss banks, is a 21st century version of Louis XVI. He feasts, the masses starve, the masses revolt.

It's a worldwide replay of the Old Testament plagues of Egypt - drought, record floods, heat and looming famine. Although climate change, both man-made and natural, are likely causes of both the crop failures and ensuing food shortages, the rising prices are also attributable to greed and an unregulated market.

In the United States, the cost of groceries went up about four percent last year, with another four percent increase in 2011. According to the public interest group Farm Policy Facts, the increases in the recent past were blamed by AgriBusiness on the hike in petroleum prices, for which an adequate explanation was never given. Remember gas prices going down as mysteriously as they'd gone up? But food prices stayed high, because we'd gotten used to paying them. The Grocery Manufacturers Association spends millions of dollars in public misinformation campaigns that blame farmers and ethanol products for the continuing high price of a box of cereal. The food industry has no reason to lower prices at the register. They're "sticky prices," the rationale being that companies don't have the incentive to lower prices once they're slapped on a product.

With the massive crop failures and increasing Chinese demand, American food companies will have no compunction about raising our food prices even higher than anticipated. Then, if by some miracle, the weather improves in a year or two, we'll still be paying through the nose. That's the American way, or more accurately, the multi-national way.

Maybe when we start having to pay half our incomes on food, and Republicans are successful in destroying the New Deal safety net, Americans will revolt too. Hungry people are angry people. Wall Street banks got a bail-out, but food banks are going bust.
